questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe epigastric discomfort and left-sided chest pain radiating to the back that began after waking up. He has also vomited several times since the pain began. He underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy the previous day for evaluation of epigastric pain. He is pale, anxious, and diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.9°C, his pulse is 140/min, his respirations are 20/min, and his blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg in his upper extremities and 108/68 mm Hg in his lower extremities. Pulse oximetry on room air shows oxygen saturation at 98%. An S4 is audible over the precordium, in addition to crepitus over the chest. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric area. A 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia with nonspecific ST-T changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophageal perforation This patient most likely has an iatrogenic esophageal perforation , which is associated with the esophagogastroduodenoscopy that was performed the day before symptom onset. Iatrogenic esophageal perforation usually occurs within 24 hours of upper endoscopy. Fever may occur as a result of a secondary infection of the mediastinum or peritoneum. Extra edge: Spontaneous rupture usually occurs on the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus into the left pleural cavity or just above the gastroesophageal junction. These patients are typically male (85%), 40 to 60 years of age, and have a history of recent emesis. Common in Alcoholics. Clinical Features : Mackler’s triad of thoracic pain, vomiting, and cervical subcutaneous emphysema is seen in spontaneous esophageal perforation.

Highyeild:

Esophageal perforation is a rare but serious condition that can be caused by both iatrogenic and spontaneous factors. Iatrogenic perforation is the most common type and can be caused by various diagnostic and therapeutic procedures, such as endoscopy, dilation, or stent placement. Spontaneous perforation is less common and can be caused by vomiting, foreign body ingestion, or underlying esophageal pathology. The most common site of iatrogenic perforation is the cervical esophagus, while spontaneous perforation typically occurs in the distal esophagus.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Pneumothorax typically presents with chest pain and may also be accompanied by subcutaneous emphysema with crepitus. However, the pain is usually described as a sharp pain that increases with inspiration. Additionally, this patient does not seem to be in significant respiratory distress since his oxygen saturation is within the normal range (98%), all of which favours another diagnosis. Option: B. Acute pancreatitis is associated with a dull pain that radiates to the back. Fever also commonly occurs and there may even be ST-T changes. Although this patient presents with radiating chest pain to the back, fever, and nonspecific ST-T changes, his crepitus over the thorax shortly following the endoscopic procedure favours a different diagnosis. Option: D . Patients with aortic dissection typically present with sudden, severe, “tearing” chest pain, radiating to the back and potential symptoms of cardiac tamponade (e.g., marked jugular venous distention, hypotension). Another important feature of aortic dissection is asymmetric blood pressure and pulses. Although this patient presents with chest pain radiating to the back, he has very similar blood pressure in his upper and lower extremities. His symptoms also occurred shortly after an endoscopic procedure, which makes another diagnosis more likely.

Extraedge:

Treatment for esophageal perforation typically involves surgical repair, which includes debridement of devitalized tissue, primary mucosal repair, and closure of the muscular layer. Tissue reinforcement with a vascular pedicle or antireflux procedure may also be used to buttress the repair. The overall mortality rate for esophageal perforation ranges from 10% to 40%, with higher rates associated with delayed diagnosis and treatment.

options.label: A

questions.correct_answer: B. Boerhaave’s syndrome is the least serious type of perforation because of the small volume of material that is released
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Boerhaave’s syndrome is the least serious type of perforation because of the small volume of material that is released Boerhaave’s syndrome is the most serious type of perforation because of the large volume of material that is released under pressure. This causes rapid chemical irritation in the mediastinum and pleura followed by infection if untreated. Thoracic perforations cause substernal and epigastric pain Mediastinal emphysema and pleural effusions are common, but early cervical subcutaneous emphysema is noted in only 20% or less of patients. Fever and sepsis develop with increasing contamination and inflammation of the mediastinum and pleural cavities. Patients with an abdominal perforation have epigastric abdominal pain that is also often referred to as the back and left shoulder.

Highyeild:

Boerhaave Syndrome Spontaneous rupture usually occurs on the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus, into the left pleural cavity or just above the gastroesophageal junction. Typically, male patients (85%) aged between 40 to 60 years with a recent history of vomiting are affected. Clinical Features Spontaneous esophageal perforation is characterized by Mackler's triad of thoracic pain, vomiting, and cervical subcutaneous emphysema. Thoracic perforations cause substernal and epigastric pain. While mediastinal emphysema and pleural effusions are common, early cervical subcutaneous emphysema is observed in only 20% or less of patients. Increasing contamination and inflammation of the mediastinum and pleural cavities lead to fever and sepsis. Patients with an abdominal perforation experience epigastric abdominal pain, which is also frequently referred to the back and left shoulder.

Explanation For other Options:- Option: A C & D. All other options are correct

Extraedge:

The diagnosis of hydropneumothorax can be confirmed by performing a contrast esophagogram, which has a high success rate of detecting extravasation in 90% of patients. To avoid the risk of barium extravasation into the pleura or mediastinum, gastrografin (a water-soluble contrast agent) is preferred over barium. If the initial esophagogram is negative, a barium study may follow. Chest CT can also aid in diagnosis by revealing mediastinal air and fluid at the perforation site. Endoscopy may be necessary if the esophagogram is negative or if surgery is planned. Treatment involves immediate resuscitation, securing the airway, administering intravenous fluids, and starting broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following factor favour non-surgical management of Esophageal perforation?
questions.correct_answer: C. Perforation confined to the mediastinum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perforation confined to the mediastinum Factors that favour non-surgical management: Small septic load large septic load Perforation confined to the mediastinum Perforation by flexible endoscope Perforation of the cervical oesophagus

Highyeild:

Conservative expectant treatment can be successful for stable patients with a clear history and contained perforation. This approach is appropriate for cervical/pharyngeal perforations where patients are less septic. Antibiotics should be administered, and patients should be kept nil by mouth while waiting for the perforation to heal on its own. Patients with intrathoracic perforations are usually sicker and require resuscitation with intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and oxygen supplementation. questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of nausea, vomiting, and retrosternal pain that radiates to the back. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric area. A CT scan of the patient's chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophageal rupture Boerhaave syndrome is most commonly caused by excessive vomiting and retching (e.g., as a result of high alcohol intake). Increased intrathoracic pressure results in elevated intra- esophageal pressure that can lead to full-thickness rupture of the esophageal wall . Patients typically have a history of vomiting and develop severe, retrosternal pain that radiates to the back. Chest auscultation often reveals a crackling or crunching sound ( Hamman sign ) due to the presence of air in soft tissue spaces. This patient's history, symptoms, and chest CT scan that shows extraluminal gas in the mediastinum (i.e., pneumomediastinum ) are consistent with a diagnosis of full-thickness esophageal rupture . Mackler triad: Retching, Chest pain, Subcutaneous emphysema. Is present in esophageal perforation.

Highyeild:

Esophageal rupture is a serious condition that can be caused by trauma or spontaneous events. Spontaneous esophageal perforation is characterized by Mackler's triad of thoracic pain, vomiting, and cervical subcutaneous emphysema. Thoracic perforations cause substernal and epigastric pain. Symptoms include chest pain, difficulty breathing, fever, and signs of shock. Diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging tests such as a CT scan or barium swallow.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Pulmonary embolism can cause sudden-onset, severe chest pain as seen in this case. Additional manifestations include dyspnea, cough, tachycardia, and hypotension. CT imaging (helical spiral CT/CT pulmonary angiography) classically shows an intraluminal filling defect of the pulmonary arteries; the presence of a wedge-shaped infarction with pleural effusion is a highly specific finding. Radiologic studies would not show pneumomediastinum. Option: C. Aortic dissection can cause retrosternal pain that radiates to the back as seen in this case. Patients typically have a history of hypertension and usually present with severely elevated blood pressure (or hypotension in cases of shock and/or cardiac tamponade). Additional manifestations include asymmetrical blood pressure readings between the arms and syncope. CT scan of patients with aortic dissection shows an intimal flap that separates a true and false lumen, not pneumomediastinum. Option: D. Acute myocardial infarction can cause nausea, vomiting, and retrosternal pain as seen in this case. Though the use of CT imaging (e.g., coronary CT angiography) is not commonly used to evaluate acute coronary syndrome, it can show atherosclerotic plaques and coronary artery stenosis. It would not be pneumomediastinum.

Extraedge:

Treatment involves surgical repair of the esophagus, although less severe cases may be managed with antibiotics and other supportive measures. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent further complications.

questions.text: Which of the following factors favours surgical management of a perforated esophagus?
questions.correct_answer: D. Perforation of the abdominal esophagus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perforation of the abdominal esophagus Factors that favour surgical repair: Large septic load Septic shock Pleura breached Boerhaave’s syndrome Perforation of the abdominal oesophagus

Highyeild:

Surgical intervention is necessary for significant sepsis when other drainage methods are ineffective and perforation closure cannot be achieved. Factors increasing the likelihood of surgical intervention include large perforation size, intrathoracic esophagus location, breached pleura, large septic load, and delayed presentation. The delayed diagnosis makes perforation closure challenging, and converting the perforation into a controlled fistula may be an alternative option. Cervical esophagostomy is rarely necessary with modern supportive treatments, and oesophagectomy is even more uncommonly required, except in cases of extensive caustic burn with perforation when the oesophagus is necrotic.

questions.text: 45-year-old man comes to the physician for difficulty swallowing and retrosternal pain for the past 4 months. He was diagnosed with lung cancer and is undergoing chemotherapy for the last 6 months. He has already tried over-the-counter antacids but they have not provided any symptom relief. He does not drink alcohol but smokes cigarettes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness. Upper endoscopy was done. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oesophageal candidiasis Oesophagitis due to Candida albicans is relatively common in patients taking steroids (especially transplant recipients) or those undergoing cancer chemotherapy. It may present with dysphagia or odynophagia. There may be visible thrush in the throat. Endoscopy shows numerous shaggy depositions. white plaques that cannot be moved, unlike food residues.

Highyeild:

GORD is the primary cause of oesophageal ulceration, but other factors can contribute, such as: Iatrogenic factors related to endoscopic procedures Presence of a nasogastric tube Certain medications like tetracyclines, potassium chloride tablets, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and bisphosphonates Medication lodged in the oesophagus can cause 'kissing' ulcers on opposite sides of the oesophagus Patients may experience odynophagia Infection of the oesophagus is more likely to occur in patients who are immunocompromised, elderly, debilitated or steroid-dependent. Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection and is characterized by adherent white pseudo-membranes.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Eosinophilic esophagitis It is characterised by eosinophilic infiltration of the oesophageal wall, presumably of allergic or idiopathic origin. The most common presenting symptom is dysphagia. The oesophagus often seems narrow and friable on endoscopy and may include mucosal rings. Option: B. CMV oesophagitis has a characteristic endoscopic appearance with a geographical, serpiginous border. Option: C. Individuals with GERD usually experience symptomatic relief with antacids. Upper endoscopy findings include mucosal erosions and strictures but not linear, longitudinal furrows.

questions.text: A 35 -year-old woman comes to the physician for difficulty swallowing and a burning sensation in her chest for the past 2 years. She has increased her fluid consumption to help with swallowing when eating. She reports having used both over-the-counter antacids and pantoprazole for 2 months without any relief of symptoms. She uses a daily low-dose inhaled corticosteroid and an albuterol inhaler as needed for allergic asthma. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Findings of an upper endoscopy are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eosinophilic esophagitis This patient’s upper endoscopy shows white , circumferential mucosal lesions (trachealisation of the esophagus ), mucosa fragility, and linear, longitudinal furrows. Dysphagia and heartburn are refractory to proton pump inhibitors in an individual with a history of atopy and are indicative of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) . A diagnosis of EoE is further supported by the findings of this patient's endoscopy (trachealization of the esophagus, longitudinal furrows, friable mucosa). Individuals with EoE may also present with food impaction, reflux, and vomiting. An endoscopic esophageal biopsy will typically show an eosinophilic infiltrate. Endoscopy shows Stacked up mucosa {Feline esophagus}

Highyeild:

Eosinophilic esophagitis (EOO) is a chronic, immune-mediated disease of the esophagus. It is characterized by symptoms related to esophageal dysfunction and eosinophil-predominant inflammation. EOO is often associated with atopic disorders and food allergies, and its incidence is increasing. Endoscopic findings of EOO include rings, furrows, exudates, and narrowing. Treatment goals include reduction of eosinophilia, control of symptoms, and normalization of endoscopic findings.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The presence of heartburn and dysphagia raises suspicion about gastroesophageal reflux disease ( GERD ). However, symptoms of GERD usually improve with proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy. GERD commonly affects the distal esophagus, which may be normal or show evidence of esophagitis; endoscopic evaluation of the upper esophagus will often be normal. Other endoscopic findings in individuals with longstanding GERD may reveal esophageal ulcers, strictures, Barrett esophagus, and/or esophageal adenocarcinoma, none of which are present in this patient. Option: B. Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors may raise suspicion for herpes (HSV) esophagitis . However, HSV esophagitis is usually present in individuals who are immunocompromised (e.g., AIDS, immunosuppressant medication use). Moreover, endoscopic evaluation of HSV esophagitis would show vesicles and multiple small superficial round/ovoid ulcers in the mid-esophagus that may coalesce to form diffuse superficial ulcers, which are not seen here. Option: C. Dysphagia and heartburn refractory to proton pump inhibitors may raise suspicion for candida esophagitis . However, candida esophagitis is typically present in individuals who are immunocompromised (e.g., AIDS, immunosuppressant medication use). Although this patient's inhaled corticosteroid increases the risk of oropharyngeal candidiasis, it is only rarely associated with esophageal candidiasis. Moreover, endoscopic evaluation of candida esophagitis would reveal white mucosal plaque-like lesions, which are not seen here.

Extraedge:

Topical corticosteroids are the mainstay of medical treatment and diet therapy may also be useful. Endoscopy is used for diagnosis, monitoring treatment progress, and therapeutic purposes. Gradual dilatations should be performed for strictures.

questions.text: What is the most common location for Schatzki's ring?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastroesophageal junction Schatzki’s ring is a circular ring in the distal esophagus Consists of a concentric symmetric narrowing representing an area of restricted distensibility of the lower esophagus Lying precisely at the squamocolumnar mucosal GEJ involves mucosa and submucosa It consists of esophageal mucosa above and gastric mucosa below It does not have a component of true esophageal muscle, nor is it associated with esophagitis It is often accompanied by a small hiatal hernia The core of the ring consists of variable amounts of fibrous tissue and cellular infiltrate. Most rings are incidental findings. Some are associated with dysphagia and respond to dilatation in conjunction with medical antireflux therapy.

Highyeild:

Schatzki’s ring A Schatzki’s ring is a circular narrowing located at the lower esophagus that restricts its distensibility in a concentric and symmetric pattern. It is found at the squamocolumnar mucosal gastroesophageal junction and affects both mucosa and submucosa. This narrowing comprises esophageal mucosa above and gastric mucosa below, lacks esophageal muscle and is not usually linked to esophagitis. A small hiatal hernia often accompanies Schatzki's ring. Clinical Features The primary symptom of Schatzki’s ring is dysphagia, which presents abruptly with almost complete obstruction and affects solid foods only. Some patients experience episodic aphagia, which is a temporary obstruction of the non-distensible ring due to large pieces of meat. Diagnosis Doctors diagnose Schatzki’s ring using a barium swallow test, with a type ‘B’ ring located at the gastroesophageal junction.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & D. are not the common locations for Schatzki’s ring.

Extraedge:

Treatment Asymptomatic patients with Schatzki's ring do not need treatment. The best way to manage symptomatic Schatzki's ring without reflux is esophageal dilation to alleviate obstructive symptoms. If the ring is associated with proven reflux and mechanically faulty sphincter, antireflux surgery is the preferred treatment. Surgical excision of the ring is not recommended because it can result in severe esophageal strictures.

questions.text: A 32 yr female was brought to casualty in an attempt of suicide and drank liquid detergent. Which of the following has no significant role in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Examination of esophagus with no significant injury

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for 3 months if severe damage with the formation of stricture

options.label: D
options.text: Early repeated endoscopy to assess the injury

questions.correct_answer: B. Use of antibiotics on prophylaxis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Use of antibiotics on prophylaxis Prophylactic use of antibiotics and steroids has no significance in the improvement of the outcome.

Highyeild:

Prophylactic use of antibiotics and steroids has no significant role in improving the outcome of a patient who attempted suicide by drinking liquid detergent. Early endoscopy to assess the injury is recommended to determine the extent of damage to the esophagus and to plan appropriate management. Examination of the esophagus is also important, even if no significant injury is found, to rule out any potential complications. Waiting for three months if severe damage with the formation of a stricture is not an appropriate course of action, as timely intervention is necessary to prevent complications.

On severe injury or late presentation there is stricture formation thus waiting for 3 months will heal the structure creating fibrous tissue. Option: D. Endoscopy should be done by trained personnel as it may cause damage to the weak esophageal wall and mucosa leading to perforation and causing further complications. questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of epigastric pain and multiple episodes of vomiting for 4 hours which was streaked with blood after binge drinking alcohol. He had 2 episodes of vomiting that contained streaks of frank blood on the way to the hospital. He has been hospitalized twice in the past year for acute pancreatitis. He drinks daily. He takes naproxen for his 'hangovers.' He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (99.1°F), his pulse is 105/min, and his blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and a tremor in his hands. The abdomen is soft and shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; there is no organomegaly. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Rectal examination is unremarkable. His haemoglobin concentration is 11.3 g/dL and his hematocrit concentration is 40%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Superficial ectatic artery in Gastric cardia

options.label: B
options.text: Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus

options.label: C
options.text: Transmural tear of the lower esophagus

options.label: D
options.text: Mucosal tear at the Gastroesophageal junction

questions.correct_answer: D. Mucosal tear at the Gastroesophageal junction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mucosal tear at the Gastroesophageal junction In Mallory-Weiss syndrome , forceful vomiting leads to longitudinal lacerations of the mucous membrane as well as the submucosal arteries and veins at the gastroesophageal junction. Esophageal injury may result in epigastric pain and hematemesis, both of which this patient is experiencing. Heavy alcohol use is the most important predisposing condition for Mallory-Weiss syndrome.

Highyeild:

Mallory-Weiss syndrome Causes: Mallory-Weiss tears occur due to forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining. Forceful contraction of the abdominal wall against an unrelaxed cardia causes mucosal laceration of proximal cardia due to an increase in intragastric pressure. The tear is partial thickness, extending through the mucosa and submucosa , resulting in disruption of gastric mucosa high on the lesser curve at cardia ( just below GE junction). Clinical Features: Common in alcoholic patients after a period of intense retching and vomiting after binge drinking. Cause of up to 15% of all severe upper GI bleeds . Arterial bleeding (usually from the left gastric artery), is usually painless and rarely associated with massive bleeding. The overall mortality rate is 3-4% , with the greatest risk for massive haemorrhage in alcoholic patients with preexisting portal hypertension. Diagnosis: Usually diagnosed by history. Endoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. A Dieulafoy lesion manifests with signs of upper GI bleeding, including hematemesis and epigastric pain. This rare condition is typically not preceded by multiple episodes of vomiting, and the haemorrhage would likely be more severe, making the diagnosis unlikely. Option: B. Esophageal varices are the most common cause of esophageal bleeding. Heavy drinking increases the risk of alcoholic liver disease and cirrhosis, which may eventually lead to the formation of esophageal varices and subsequent variceal bleeding. Variceal bleeding usually manifests with sudden onset of hematemesis, which is seen here. However, this patient had multiple episodes of non-bloody vomiting before the bleeding started and has only been vomiting a small amount of blood, whereas variceal bleeding would typically manifest with severe haemorrhage. Because his physical examination did not show any signs of liver disease or portal hypertension, a different diagnosis is more likely. Option: C. The patient's history of epigastric pain following multiple episodes of vomiting due to heavy alcohol use should raise suspicion for a transmural tear of the lower esophagus, as seen in Boerhaave syndrome. However, hematemesis is not characteristic of this condition. In addition, patients with Boerhaave syndrome typically present with excruciating retrosternal chest pain rather than epigastric pain and can develop dyspnea, crepitus of palpation of the chest wall (due to mediastinal emphysema), and signs of mediastinitis, none of which is seen here.

Extraedge:

Supportive therapy is often all that is necessary because 90% of bleeding episodes are self-limited, and the mucosa often heals within 72 hours. Persistent bleeding is managed by endoscopic electrocoagulation or endoscopic therapy with injection , angiographic embolization, or surgery (laparotomy and high gastrotomy with oversewing of the linear tear) if the above manoeuvres fail. Recurrent bleeding from a Mallory-Weiss tear is uncommon. Note: A Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is contraindicated in Mallory-Weiss syndrome as it will not stop bleeding due to arterial pressure.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of chest and epigastric pain that started just after vomiting 30 minutes ago. She does not take any medications. While in the emergency department, the patient experiences two episodes of forceful, bloody emesis. Her temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), her pulse is 110/minute, and her blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dental enamel erosion and calluses on the dorsal aspect of her right hand. Russell’s sign was present. There is tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. An x-ray of the chest is normal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

options.label: D
options.text: Mucosal lacerations at the Gastroesophageal junction

questions.correct_answer: D. Mucosal lacerations at the Gastroesophageal junction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mucosal lacerations at the Gastroesophageal junction Mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction are found in Mallory-Weiss syndrome, which is the cause of this patient's epigastric pain, forceful hematemesis, and unstable vitals (indicating hypovolemic shock). Conditions associated with frequent forceful vomiting, such as this patient's presumed bulimia nervosa, predispose to Mallory-Weiss syndrome. Other predisposing conditions include alcohol abuse disorder, hiatal hernia, and GERD. Russell’s sign is seen in patients with bulimia nervosa : Erosion/pigmentation on Lnuclies due to repeated attempts to induce vomiting. The clinical presentation of the chest and epigastric pain, vomiting, and hematemesis with dental enamel erosion and calluses on the dorsal aspect of her right hand and Russell's sign (caused by repeated knuckle abrasions from inducing vomiting) suggest the diagnosis of bulimia nervosa. Further evaluation with upper endoscopy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of damage to the esophagus and stomach. The most likely finding, in this case, is mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction, also known as Mallory-Weiss tears, which are caused by forceful vomiting.

Highyeild:

Mallory-Weiss tear Longitudinal tear at the GOJ caused by repetitive and strenuous vomiting. Lesions can occur without causing bleeding. When it causes haematemesis, the lesion may be difficult to see as it is just below the GOJ and hard to spot for inexperienced endoscopists. Sometimes these lesions continue to bleed and need surgery.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa result from esophageal varices secondary to cirrhosis or Dieulafoy's lesion. Both conditions can also cause haemorrhage, hematemesis, retrosternal or epigastric pain, and shock, as seen in this patient. However, neither condition is associated with bulimia nervosa, and given a lack of signs of cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, ascites) and the rarity of Dieulafoy's lesions, another diagnosis is more likely. Option: B. Transmural rupture of the distal esophagus, or Boerhaave syndrome, can present with hematemesis, severe retrosternal or epigastric pain, and can lead to shock, as in this patient. However, patients classically have crepitus of the chest due to subcutaneous emphysema and a pneumomediastinum on CXR. Option: C. A clean-based gastric ulcer, suggestive of peptic ulcer disease (PUD), can also present with hematemesis and epigastric pain. However, given the acute nature of this patient's pain and forceful vomiting, as well as a history negative for PUD risk factors (e.g., NSAID or corticosteroid use, smoking, no previous heartburn), this diagnosis is unlikely.

Extraedge:

Persistent bleeding in Mallory Weiss Syndrome can be managed through different methods, including: Endoscopic electrocoagulation or endoscopic therapy with injection Angiographic embolization Surgery, which involves laparotomy and high gastrotomy with oversewing of the linear tear, only if the above methods fail.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has a sudden onset of massive emesis of bright red blood. On physical examination, his temperature is 36.9° C, the pulse is 103/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 85/50 mm Hg. His spleen tip is palpable. Laboratory studies show a hematocrit of 21%. The serologic test result for HBsAg is positive. He has had no prior episodes of hematemesis. The hematemesis is most likely to be a consequence of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophageal varices Variceal bleeding is a common complication of hepatic cirrhosis , which can be an outcome of chronic hepatitis B infection . Portal hypertension leads to dilated submucosal esophageal veins that can erode and bleed profusely.

Highyeild:

Esophageal varices Portal hypertension (PHT) is primarily associated with the development of gastroesophageal (GE) varices , with the major blood supply to these varices being the anterior branch of the left gastric or coronary vein . Variceal bleeding is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality associated with PHT. Approximately 30% of patients with compensated cirrhosis and 60% of patients with decompensated cirrhosis have esophageal varices, and one-third of all patients with varices experience variceal bleeding. Each episode of bleeding is associated with a 20-30% risk of mortality , and 70% of patients who survive the initial bleed will experience recurrent variceal haemorrhage within one year if left untreated. Current measures aimed at preventing variceal bleeding include abstaining from alcohol to improve liver function, avoiding aspirin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and administering nonselective beta-blockers such as propranolol or nadolol.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Barrett esophagus is a columnar metaplasia that results from gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Bleeding is not a key feature of this disease. Option: B. Esophageal candidiasis may be seen in immunocompromised patients, but it most often produces raised mucosal plaques and is rarely invasive. Option: D. GERD may produce acute and chronic inflammation and, rarely, massive haemorrhage.

Extraedge:

Pharmacologic therapy can start as soon as variceal bleeding is diagnosed. Vasopressin is the most potent vasoconstrictor but has many side effects and should be used for a short time only. Somatostatin and octreotide cause splanchnic vasoconstriction. Octreotide is preferred for the initial management of acute variceal bleeding.

Solution:

Sengstaken Blakemore tube Sengstaken Blakemore tube has 3 lumen. It has ports for gastric and esophageal balloons and a gastric aspiration port.

Highyeild:

Sengstaken Blakemore tube The Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used to control bleeding from esophageal or gastric varices and has three lumens. Modifications to the original design include the addition of a fourth port above the esophageal balloon for more effective aspiration of oral and esophageal secretions and the development of a single balloon Linton-Nachlas tube for gastric varices. Airway protection is recommended during placement, and water or oily contrast media should not be used to inflate the balloon. The gastric balloon is inflated with 50 mL of air and then 250 mL of air after positioning, and the esophageal balloon may be inflated to a pressure of 40 mm Hg if bleeding continues. Aspiration pneumonia is the most common complication.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Minnesota tube has 4 lumens with an additional esophageal aspiration port. Both are used in the management of upper GI haemorrhage. The balloon is inflated and pressure is applied to the bleeding varices. Option: C.Nasogastric tube is used for Feeding To prevent aspiration in comatose patients Gastric wash {It does not have any balloon for pressure ligation.} Option: D. Foley catheter is used to drain the urine, and is put into the urinary bladder through the urethra. It too has a single inflatable bulb in front which holds the catheter in its place.
